name: NPR
text: What did it take for Chadwick Boseman to become one of the biggest movie stars of the past decade? Today on #NPRConsiderThis, we look at his path and what his success reveals about race in America — and in Hollywood. https://t.co/y8xlfosr4z

name: NPR
text:
D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser said outside agitators came to the city over the weekend, intent on battling police. 70% of those arrested in the unrest came from outside D.C., police say.
https://t.co/mWVU4ExqkF

name: NPR
text:
President Trump declined to condemn the actions of the suspected 17-year-old shooter of 3 protesters against police brutality in Kenosha — claiming, without evidence, that it appeared the gunman was acting in self-defense.
https://t.co/a7LnGABckN

name: NPR
text:
In Iowa, Pres. Trump has only approved federal assistance for individuals in one Iowa county. There are 27 who asked for aid in the wake of the derecho, which has now been determined to have been the intensity of a Category 4 hurricane. (@IowaPublicRadio)

https://t.co/lh63yXm6qa

name: NPR
text:
Zoom has reported higher sales and profit in the 3 months from May through July than it did in all of 2019. The company's shares surged 25% in after-hours trading on Monday.
https://t.co/auyblaJMDI

name: NPR
text:
Dime Davis, the director of HBO's "A Black Lady Sketch Show," could soon become the first Black woman to win an Emmy for directing a television series.

"It's still very surreal to me," she says.
https://t.co/vdSgg14Hiz

name: NPR
text:
It's normal to want to avoid conflict — and lots of people do.

Here are some tools for turning what could be a heated argument into something constructive, so both parties feel like they're working together. (@nprlifekit)
https://t.co/8JpXVITaVd

name: NPR
text:
The very first episode of @OnlyAGameNPR featured a story about an eccentric former MLB pitcher. It set the stage for many stories to come. 
https://t.co/67RXXKyE2V

name: NPR
text:
Revenue is down between 75% to 95% across San Francisco's public transit system, says the agency's director. 

Without additional federal aid, he says the agency will “burn our reserves” to keep the system running and prevent layoffs. @hereandnow https://t.co/0XSle14k6V

name: NPR
text:
Millions of Americans live in a potential path of a hurricane. But research suggests people are confused by common graphics and warnings about where storms are headed and the risks they pose. 

Here's a simple guide to help you out.
https://t.co/IFPtMZJ2lq

name: NPR
text:
Republicans have readopted the same platform that propelled President Trump to the White House in 2016. 

But partisanship and GOP divisions prevented much of that agenda from ever becoming law, grounding Washington nearly to a halt. https://t.co/aIcYIBN5gJ

name: NPR
text: Throughout her time in politics, Kamala Harris has found herself caught between two very different groups that see themselves in her — law enforcement and progressive activists pushing for a more racially just legal system. https://t.co/kQ0HqybcIw

name: NPR
text:
In January, the Trump administration issued a memo to let CBP agents handle early screenings of asylum-seekers —arguing their training is comparable to Citizenship and Immigration Services.

A federal judge called it "poppycock" and has blocked the change.
https://t.co/tXKvtq9M1H

name: NPR
text:
L.A. County sheriff's deputies shot and killed a Black man on Monday, sparking a protest and an investigation by homicide detectives.

In a news briefing, an official didn't specify what crime the man had been suspected of before deputies approached.
https://t.co/t0vCixcoME

name: NPR
text:
A group of 52 Black former McDonald's franchisees are suing the fast-food giant of discrimination, alleging they faced harsher scrutiny and were steered toward neighborhoods where sales are lower while costs are higher.
https://t.co/MihTqiEQrF

name: NPR
NPR
text:
José spent 3 months in the hospital being treated for COVID-19. Then he came home to his wife and kids — on a ventilator and with a feeding tube.

Now, it’s up to his wife to do the medical care.
https://t.co/X0P4h7dS6J

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. Open kicked off on Monday, absent one of its most iconic hallmarks — the crowd.

Organizers say they're following specific safety protocols, including masks when not on the court, social distancing and frequent testing.
https://t.co/YOUNymrB7l

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is visiting Kenosha, despite the mayor and governor urging him to put off his visit.

He plans to meet with police and tour a section of the city damaged by rioting. He said Monday that he didn't plan to meet with Jacob Blake's family.
https://t.co/i0Rwk0gfZl

name: NPR
text:
California has extended measures aimed at preventing millions of people from being evicted for late rent payments due to the pandemic.

Under the new legislation, tenants who pay at least 25% of their rent from Sept. 1 through Jan. 31 will be protected.
https://t.co/6mWNWmDiuc

name: NPR
text:
For cities, as well as their tax bases, empty commercial real estate presents a crisis still looming.

Companies realize they can work remotely, an analyst says, "They're thinking, 'Hey, do I really need this much office space?' "
https://t.co/l7nkWag6kS

name: NPR
text: WATCH LIVE: President Trump is in Kenosha, Wis., the site of racial unrest after police shot Jacob Blake. https://t.co/rPqUHwGoFw

name: NPR
text: Walmart is launching its competitor to Amazon Prime: an annual membership service giving shoppers free delivery of groceries and other perks, such as a discount on gas and mobile checkout at stores.  https://t.co/rWLOIPppt0
